awd_titl_txt: Polar (DCL- 16-119): Development and Evaluation of an Interdisciplinary Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience in Arctic Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
A team of scientists and educators at Arizona State University will develop and implement a highly interdisciplinary Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) to engage students in polar research. The interdisciplinary experience will pair undergraduate students from both science and non-science majors to conduct group research projects in the Arctic and to design innovative ways to communicate results to the public. During the course, students will compare the Arctic ecosystems, specifically ecosystems at the Kilpisjärvi Biological Research Station in northern Finland, with those from the desert environment in which they currently reside. Research opportunities for students range from Arctic ecosystem studies to use of the Kilpisjärvi Atmospheric Imaging Receiver Array, a dual array of omnidirectional VHF radio antennas focused on auroras. Through this innovative learning opportunity, students will design, implement and present both an independent science-based research project and a communications project to explain their findings. Student participants will be selected from the diverse student body at Arizona State University's West Campus. 


The intellectual merit of the project rests on the effectiveness of this pilot CURE, which will be evaluated using a mixed method approach to determine how the experience impacted student learning and how it impacts student interest in scientific research and in postgraduate studies. The broader impacts of the project include involving students from diverse backgrounds, including minorities, first-generation college students and veterans, in polar research and training students in the effective communication of science. This project offers an opportunity to determine the impact of a short international research experience on diverse students. In addition, the two years of support for this course will lay the foundation for the future iterations of the course, which are planned to be self-sustaining.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit      We developed and implemented a highly interdisciplinary, immersive field research course that blends science and art curriculum with course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) to engage a diverse audience of future scientists. This cross-discipline experience paired undergraduate students from both science and non-science (art-related) majors to conduct and communicate group research projects focusing on the ecology of Arctic and desert ecosystems. These are two ecosystems that, much like science and art, seem like ‘polar opposites’ but actually have a lot of similarities. Through this innovative learning opportunity, students designed, implemented and presented both an independent science-based research project and an artistic work to communicate their findings.

The effectiveness of this pilot program was evaluated to determine how the interdisciplinary research experience impacted student learning, attitudes and conceptualizations about the sciences and arts, their self-efficacy as scientists, and career goals. We also compared students traveling for an immersive research experience at a field station in the Arctic to those who worked entirely from their home ecosystem in the Sonoran Desert. We found that students in both the local-only and travel-abroad sections of the course found new or deeper connections between art and science, developed a more sophisticated understanding of the scientific method, became more confident with their science skills, and reported an expanded perspective on their future careers (often including field work and a wider geographic job search). Science–art student teams appreciated the connections between science and art, noting that they are “two sides of the same coin”. They also indicated that the course provided them with a more authentic research experience that led them to seek other opportunities for future collaborative work. Additionally, the travel abroad students benefitted from experiencing new ecosystems and cultures, from working with science and art professionals from other countries, and from working in an isolated field station without distractions. Our findings demonstrate that even if the field experience is relatively short, the immersive nature of field research and the interdisciplinary interactions between art and science students enhanced science students’ confidence levels in their understanding of the science behind environmental issues, as well as their communication skills and recognition of the importance of collaboration.

 

Broader Impacts       STEM pedagogy: By integrating polar research into effective STEM education, our program trained students to become the next generation of scientists and science communicators, while broadening the participation of students gaining access to polar research efforts as undergraduates. The assessment of this pilot course documented how student participation in the course improves student learning, generates student interest in research, and fosters interest in collaboration, thus advancing not only student learning, but also the scholarship of teaching. Results were disseminated in a peer-reviewed pedagogical journal and at national STEM education conferences and workshops to reach faculty in the sciences considering interdisciplinary CUREs. Educational resources: The teaching materials developed for the college curriculum are freely available online (https://sites.google.com/asu.edu/bioart), along with adaptations across K-12 grade levels. The K-12 curricula were designed to fit with the existing Standards of Learning, to make it readily apparent to teachers how they can incorporate these exercises into their classrooms. They were also disseminated along with needed supplies to local schools through education fairs and summer camps. Science communication: The college students’ projects have been showcased publicly to spread the results of their research to the general public, both through local community events as well as globally through an online “virtual exhibit”. This extends the reach of the program beyond the immediate local community that could attend the live exhibitions.
